In this assignment, we will be working with a dataset reporting the number of crimes by month in Prince George's County, Maryland, for every month in 2024. 

### Task 1: Load the Tidyverse

You will need to load the tidyverse library

```{r}
library(tidyverse)
```

Then you'll load the data from the web. The URL for the data is: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dwillis/jour405/refs/heads/main/data/pg_crime_totals_2024.csv. You will create a dataframe called `pg_crime` that contains the data from this URL.

### Task 2: Load the Data and Describe It

```{r}
pg_crime <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dwillis/jour405/refs/heads/main/data/pg_crime_totals_2024.csv")
```

### Task 4: Calculating Averages

Calculate the total number of incidents per month for each category using `mutate()`, calling the new column `total_incidents`. Then calculate the average number of incidents per month for each category of crime, calling the new column `average_incidents`. Assign the result to a new dataframe called `pg_crime_averages`.

```{r}
total_incidents <- pg_crime |>  mutate(total_incidents =  rowSums(across(2:13)))

pg_crime_averages <- total_incidents |> mutate(average_incidents = total_incidents / 12)
```

### Task 5: Describe the Averages

Examine the new dataframe, `pg_crime_averages`, by clicking on it in the Environment tab in RStudio. ANSWER HERE:

### Task 6: Testing a Theory

One theory about crime is that it is more likely to occur in the summer months. Test this theory by creating three new columns using `mutate()` that calculate the percentage change compared to the average for each category of crime for the months of June, July, and August. Call the new columns `june_change`, `july_change`, and `august_change`. Assign the result to a new dataframe called `summer_crime_averages`.

```{r}
summer_crime_averages <- pg_crime_averages |> mutate(june_change = (Jun - average_incidents)/average_incidents * 100)

summer_crime_averages <- pg_crime_averages |> mutate(jul_change = (Jul - average_incidents)/average_incidents * 100)

summer_crime_averages <- pg_crime_averages |> mutate(aug_change = (Aug - average_incidents)/average_incidents * 100)

```

### Task 7: Describe the Summer Crime Averages

Look at the `summer_crime_averages` dataframe by clicking on it in the Environment tab in RStudio. Write a couple of sentences describing the percentage change in the average number of incidents per month for each category of crime for the months of June, July, and August. Do you see any patterns? What does this tell you about the theory that crime is more likely to occur in the summer months?

ANSWER HERE:
June categories generally saw an increase in crimes per month as compared to the monthly averages, though there were a few exceptions (B&E Other, Commercial Robbery, Assaults, Accidents, etc.). Nevertheless, in June, 11 of the 18 categories saw percent increases from their monthly averages, with seven of those categories seeing increases north of 10%. 

As for July, crime averages take a dip, with over half of the categories seeing frequencies below their yearly averages. B&E Other, Assaults, and Accidents once again fall into this category. Vehicular crimes once again stay relatively high, with Vehicle Robbery (64.5% increase from the monthly average), Stolen & Recovered Auto (42.9% increase from the monthly average), and Theft from Auto (14.6% increase from the monthly average) all seeing noteworthy percentage rises. 

August is similar to July in the sense that generally, crime percentages are lower than their monthly category averages, but the categories themselves are a bit peculiar. Vehicle Robberies were relatively high in both June and July, but that trend reversed in August, with a 15.7% decrease from the monthly average. A similar pattern also occurred with Sex Offenses being relatively low in August. Conversely, Shooting Assaults were relatively low in June, but spiked in July, and even more so in August. 

Overall, the data is more scattered than I expected, with there being significant month-to-month changes in certain categories. But overall, I think the data would reject the theory that crime is more likely to occur during the summer, since there's ultimately a fair amount of month-to-month volatility. I also think you would need several years (or even a decade) worth of data to properly evaluate whether or not crime is more frequent during the summer.
